awd_abstract_narration:
Extensive ways to measure research and development activity exist, but there is a gap in being able to measure frontier research topics. This project develops new indicators of technological emergence to support researchers, research managers, businesses, and others in identifying key topics at the frontiers of science and technology. Distinguishing cutting edge research and development activities can inform strategy development and reveal new opportunities. Being able to measure emergent topics additionally enables sharper research program assessment. Indicators of which countries, organizations, or individuals are contributing most to advances in a given domain provide vital competitive technical intelligence. The project's new technological emergence indicators focus on frontier contributions to complement general science, technology, and innovation indicators. We formulate a suite of indicators, develop software routines to calculate them, and devise reports and visualizations to communicate to different audiences, including researchers, managers, and policy makers.

The project implements a four-attribute model of what constitutes technological emergence. Emergent topics should evidence term novelty, persistence, and accelerating growth, plus show formation of a research community. The approach extracts records on given science and technology topics from global research publication and patent databases. The research experiments with different ways to clean and consolidate those records' topical content. Then the project devises software scripts to score topics' degree of emergence. The computational algorithm then scores actors in given research areas, such as research organizations or countries, based on the extent to which the actors work on the  highly emerging topics. The makeup of the scores and how they behave is then studied through nine diversified science and technology case studies. Testing includes a series of sensitivity analyses across fields and time periods. The testing seeks to validate the emergence indicators by analyzing their performance in predicting research and development activity in a subsequent one-to-three-year period. These new technological emergence indicators will be examined in conjunction with established science and technology metrics to help assess research and development capabilities and opportunities. The project will explore ways to apply the emergence indicators, such as gauging how government funding programs advance cutting edge research topic activity, or tracking diffusion of topical content from research to patents to commercialization arenas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The essence of this project research consists of 23 journal articles (listed in the Final Report) that address a spectrum of analyses of emerging technologies. Those describe how we search in research publication and patent abstract databases (such as Web of Science and PubMed), to then devise indicators of Science, Technology and Innovation (ST&I) emergence.  The project emphasizes intelligent bibliometrics -- applying Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools to provide useful indicators of R&D frontier research concentrations and directions.

Those 23 project-derived papers offer case analyses of some 10 technologies: nanotechnology, nanomedicine, triboelectric nanogenerators, microneedles, COVID, autonomous vehicles, synthetic biology, gene editing, 3D printing, and deep learning. 

The key theme is connecting R&D.  We want to develop an integrated suite of aids to help researchers and research managers locate and utilize pertinent research appearing in diverse places. 

One timely target for which to strive to connect research efforts is Long COVID [see DOI 10.3389/frma.2023.1149091].  Figure 1 shows our recent Long COVID research dashboard -- https://searchtechnology.github.io/LongCovidDashboard/.

The dashboard provides flexible means to identify "who is doing what, where?" on a chosen research topic in the domain.

To illustrate -- this Long COVID research profile helps find connections among 5,243 records on the topic, as of January, 2023.  One of the dashboard interfaces is a VizLink(R) chart, shown in Figure 1.  There you can see:

  • Our algorithm has identified some 13 topics, of which we have selected cognitive deficits (addressed in 632 papers).
  • We have then focused on the subset of cognitive deficit papers with one or more authors from the U.S. (130 of the 632 papers)
  • And, a step further, we spotlight 47 of those 130 papers that concern research relating to fatigue, in conjunction with cognitive deficits.

You could then browse those 47 titles and open abstract records of interest.  Then, you could click on a URL to grab the paper that you want to read (Figure 2).  You can also focus on what particular researchers are emphasizing (e.g., by reading Dale Needham's papers on the target topic).  The second image shows one of those papers via PubMed .  So, in a minute, you can track a research thread of interest.

Note that the papers offer full text searchability to find particular topics or researchers. The interface also enables tracking along citation paths.   Papers provide references (backward citation), and they show URLs for a next generation of papers that have cited a given paper (forward citation). 

We aspire to extend such efforts at connecting R&D beyond the search domain (e.g., Long COVID in this illustration).  We have pilot tested an AI method -- knowledge modeling (KM) -- that generates sets of similar and dissimilar terms using their average Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF).  The KM is then applied to search beyond the target domain -- to identify other research that relates importantly to the target topic, but was not captured in the domain search (here, Long COVID).  We have applied this Literature Based Discovery (LBD) approach to the full PubMed database [now containing over 35 million records] to find other research papers likely to pertain to target research interests.1 

1Wu, M., Zhang, Y., Markley, M., Cassidy, C., Newman, N., and Porter, A. (2022), Covid-19 knowledge deconstruction and retrieval: Solutions of intelligent bibliometrics, Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL) Workshop on Extraction and Evaluation of Knowledge Entities from Scientific Documents (EEKE2022), Cologne, Germany & Online.[under revision for possible publication in Scientometrics]
